text: Patient: Last week, yes, and my PSA jumped up tremendously. This is from last year. This is December and this is last week – up point five. Doctor: Blood count is good, tab - nothing dramatic – sporadic just below the normal range. So your kidney function goes up and down. So two months hundred at one point six, then it was repeated back down to one and then it was up at one point five. Where did you have your scan last week? Patient: In Hospital A in B___. I have the information and phone number. Doctor: So is G___ a new doctor for you or have you seen him for a while? Patient: No, that was only the second visit. And I saw him after, thoracic surgeon in Hospital B and spotted through tests, prostate cancer cells in my liver, and also on my lung Family Member: December. Patient: And that’s when he recommended I see an oncologist there. He teaches up here, too, so. He’s kind of the go-between. And he’s the one that said he’d work on the lung problem. Doctor: Just a couple more things So other than the CAT scan you haven’t had any other new scans? Patient: Not for I think about two months, three months, and I had the whole-body scan ordered by I think the thoracic surgeon V___ and that’s been the three lymph nodes on the lungs. Doctor: And that’s all you know from the last time you were here. Patient: Oh no, not since the last time I was here, no, just that one. Doctor: Okay, uh so the test results that we have is your ARV7 test. Dr. G but we had one- Patient: Uh hum.

text: Patient: Really? Doctor: Yeah. I thought you’d like that. Downside if you have to be here all the time. It’s three times a week. Can you imagine vitamin C flitters outta your system. Patient: It does. Doctor: So this is a J___ study that we’re hoping to open within the next… Doctor: …Yeah, probably within the next month. Patient: Neither one of you know what the term ‘really old’ means. Doctor: That’s true. That’s true. Patient: Thank you. (laughs) Doctor: Um but that’s an option where… Patient: I’m working on year seventy-four so I’m hanging in there. Doctor: Doing pretty darn good. Um but I think the the downside of that trial is you’re here all the time, but the plus side is you’re getting you know the chemo is a standard and the vitamin C we’ll see what happens so. Patient: Yeah. If I need to cancel that trip… Doctor: Okay.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, it has less side effects than chemotherapy but has more risks than chemotherapy because if we do turn on your immune system really good, attack you, you could be bad. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay? Family Member: That’s if it ends up going bad versus -- uh, activated immune system. Doctor: We often use steroids, and we try to sort of dampen it – Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And some folks – most people recover. Uh, but we have to hold the drugs, not hold the drugs, and then, -- yeah, so it’s a catch twenty-two, uh, that, you know, it also is for individuals like you who again have some factor that tells us that your cancer is not gonna bode well with, you know, your survival from this cancer is not, you know, tremendously long. Patient: I, I was told I’ll see another Christmas. Doctor: Yeah. That could be true, or it could be a little bit longer. But, again, most of the time when we’ve used the docetaxel – the Taxotere that you got that you started in the fall? Uh. We tell folks that from that setting, we sort of says that people live fifteen to twenty months. Eh, so that’s when we may get to the end of this year. Uh. And so that’s where you also may step back and say, “Whoa. If time is short, I don’t want to be sick. I don’t want to have to go to the doctor. I don’t wanna be all of this other stuff. Uh. Let me focus on me.” Okay? And work on just keeping you comfortable. ‘Cuz right now, you’re comin’ and goin’, gettin’ exhausted at five o’clock. You’re takin’ your nap and – you know, getting your cleaning done the next day. Patient: Five. Yeah. So. Doctor: So, that is – some people do just sort of say, “Look. You know, I’ve been through everything, and I don’t know if I can do much more. And I wanna just sort of be comfortable.” Other folks say, “Okay. There’s more drugs? Give ‘em to me.” Okay? Patient: Yeah.

text: Patient: And he’s said he’s had good luck with other patients that have had pain with that Cymbalta. Doctor: In the joints? I mean I don’t know how it will help with that with your pain, but you know what it’s definitely worth a try. I have no objections to giving that a try but I’m not terribly hopeful, but if he’s seen something different in his experience. Patient: Well if that’s the case I’ll just stay on the prednisone. Forget that. I mean it’s not something Doctor: Okay I mean I’m okay if you want to give that a try Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: and there’s no objection or problem - Patient: Okay. Doctor: from the study standpoint. Patient: Alright, Okay. Family Member: Which is the lesser of the two evils as far as taking it long term? I’m not familiar with Cymbalta. Doctor: Well, I think Cymbalta is probably you know much more proven you know long term. The steroids can have other issues of you know blocking the immune systems likely increased risk of infections and things like that over the long term, but you know it’s – I kind of think it’s unlikely that it will help arthritic pain. If it is neuropathic nerve pain and stuff, you know Cymbalta can be effective. Patient: Yeah I think that’s what he said also yeah. Doctor: I don’t think that is the reason for your pain, but that’s my impression.

text: Family Member: So we’re still kind of up in the air because this is nothing we can cure because of the type of cancer that it is and there’s no option to remove the lymph node. I don’t know Doctor: That’s correct. Family Member: That’s correct. Okay, okay. So with him trying to maintain quality of life and, and, and, uhm you know stay upright knowing that he has this and that he’s against hormone therapy but also still leaning with the fact that there’s the other foot to drop. Doctor: Uh hum. Family Member: You’re saying the radiation is a viable option if that’s the route he chooses to go but your recommendation is hormone? Doctor: No actually open to both; it all depends on your current wishes. If your wish is to preserve your quality of life as much as possible for as long as possible – Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - then there’s no question that hormone therapy will cause more side effects than radiation. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: There’s no question about that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, if your goal is to try to eradicate as much of the cancer as fast as possible –

text: Patient: So is it in somewhere in comparison…? Well I guess they’re two independent things then. Doctor: It’s two, it’s two independent things. You are a extremely low risk gist tumor. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And and the risk is not determined by the size. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s determined by um how rapidly the cells are dividing, so there’s something that’s called a mitosis. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: A mitosis means however the cell’s dividing. And you have like the very lowest mitotic rate. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So your gist basically it’s it’s a really dumb one; it doesn’t really know how to metastasize. So when you’ve got a cancer, you’d rather have a dumb one than a smart one. You had a really dumb gist tumor. But you’ve kind of got a smarter prostate cancer. So the gist tumor I think is extremely unlikely… Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: …to spread to a lymphnode although it is theoretically possible. But what is far more likely given the fact that you have a prostate cancer with you know high Gleason score and a PSA that is rising… Patient: Uh hum.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
